content.question: Let f be a continuous function on the closed interval [-3,6]. If <math> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mo>−</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </math> and <math> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>6</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn> </mrow> </math>, then the Intermediate Value Theorem guarantees that

choices.label: <math> <mrow> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>c</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mfrac> <mn>4</mn> <mn>9</mn> </mfrac> </mrow> </math> for at least one c between -3 and 6
f(c)=1 for at least one c between -3 and 6
f(c)=0 for at least one c between -1 and 3

content.answer: f(c)=1 for at least one c between -3 and 6

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 3.E: Provide reasons or rationales for solutions and conclusions.
